eu.toolchain.concurrent

Interface Managed<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - type of the managed reference
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    ReloadableManaged<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ConcurrentManaged

    public interface Managed<T>
    Managed lightweight, reference-counted objects.

    This utility class guarantees that the underlying reference has been initialized and that the block of code using it will never operate on an invalid reference.

    An invalid reference is an object that has been freed or destructed before it is being used. An example would be a database connection that has been closed, any subsequent actions on it is very likely to cause an exception to be thrown. By wrapping the connection in a managed reference, any block of code using the reference prevents it from being deconstructed until it is no longer being used.

    Since we cannot rely on the garbage collector being invoked in a timely fashion, the borrowed references has to be manually released. Fortunately, there are some helpers to ease this like doto(Function), the try-with-resources pattern on a Borrowed reference, and the Borrowed.release() method.

    This pattern is useful if you have a block of code returning a future. It guarantees that the code is executed in a safe fashion, that will release the reference if it throws an exception. After it has successfully returned a future, the borrowed reference will be released when this future is completed: 

    
   final Managed<Database> m;

   final Stage<Integer> future = m.doto(db -> {
     // do something with database
     return db.count();
   });

    The following is an example using try-with-resource: 

    
   final Managed<T> m = ...;

   try (final Borrowed<T> b = m.borrow()) {
     final T value = b.get();

     // do something with 'value'.
   }

    Finally, this is how you manually borrow and release the reference after use: 

    
   final Managed<T> m = ...;

   final Managed.Borrowed<T> b = m.borrow();

   try {
     final T value = b.get();

     // do something with 'value'.
   } finally {
     b.release();
   }

    Managed references are prime candidates for leaking references. This is caused by application code not having a 1:1 correspondence between each borrow() and Borrowed.release() call.

    To aid troubleshooting, Borrowed references have implemented the Object.finalize() that provides instrumentation through Caller.referenceLeaked(Object, StackTraceElement[]) if the borrowed reference is garbage collected before it has been released. Stack traces are only captured if the system property defined by CAPTURE_STACK is set to yes.

    Additionally, tracing for each managed reference can be enabled by setting the system property defined by TRACING to yes. This causes the managed reference's Object.toString() to contain detailed information about every borrowed reference that has currently been acquired. Like the following example:
    Author:
    udoprog

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static String CAPTURE_STACK
      System property that if set to 'yes', will cause stacks to be captured by borrowed references.
      static String TRACING
      System property that if set to 'yes', will cause the managed references to be traced.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Borrowed<T> borrow()
      Borrow the underlying reference.
      <U> Stage<U> doto(Function<? super T,? extends Stage<U>> action)
      Borrow a reference and execute the given action.
      boolean isReady()
      If managed reference is started, but not stopping or stopped.
      Stage<Void> start()
      Start the managed reference.
      Stage<Void> stop()
      Stop the underlying managed reference.

    • Field Detail

      • TRACING

        static final String TRACING
        System property that if set to 'yes', will cause the managed references to be traced.

      • CAPTURE_STACK

        static final String CAPTURE_STACK
        System property that if set to 'yes', will cause stacks to be captured by borrowed references.

        This will cause managed references to be more memory intensive.

    • Method Detail

      • start

        Stage<Void> start()
        Start the managed reference.
        Returns:
        a stage associated with the starting of the managed reference.

      • stop

        Stage<Void> stop()
        Stop the underlying managed reference.

        If called multiple times will only A stop call will do the following (in order):

        • subsequent borrowed references are not valid
        • waits for the reference count to become zero, this indicates that no one is using the reference
        • destruct the managed reference
        Returns:
        s stage associated with the stopping of the managed reference

      • borrow

        Borrowed<T> borrow()
        Borrow the underlying reference.

        This reference must be explicitly released, otherwise the application could leak reference which will cause stop() to misbehave

        Returns:
        A borrowed reference.

      • doto

        <U> Stage<U> doto(Function<? super T,? extends Stage<U>> action)
        Borrow a reference and execute the given action.

        The reference will be released when the action's future is finished:

         
   final Managed<Database> m = ...;

   return m.doto(db -> {
     return db.query(...);
   });
        Type Parameters:
        U - the type of the return value from the action
        Parameters:
        action - The action to perform on the borrowed reference.
        Returns:
        The future returned by the action.

      • isReady

        boolean isReady()
        If managed reference is started, but not stopping or stopped.

        Should only be used for diagnostical purposes. Code using references should utilize futures returned by methods like start() and stop() to know when there reference is ready.

        Returns:
        true if the underlying reference is constructed, and available to be borrowed.
